Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Controlled motion of nanoscale objects is the first step to achieve integrated nanomachinary systems that can enable break-through applications in nanoelectronics, photonics, bioengineering, and drug delivery or disease treatment. Naturally occurring nanomotors are biological motor proteins powered by catalytic reactions. Unlike the nanomotors in nature, most artificial nanomotors are usually powered by external fields. Recently it has been demonstrated that using a simple catalytic reaction and an asymmetric bimetallic nanorod, one can produce catalytic nanomotors that mimic certain dynamic behaviors of bionanomotors. This research has shined a light for humans to be able to construct complicated nanomachines which mimic biological behavior. Yet, the construction of artificial nanomachines remains a major contemporary challenge due to the lack of a flexible fabrication technique that can design the desired dynamic components. Recent research in our laboratories has demonstrated that a nanofabrication technique based on shadowing growth and dynamic substrate manipulation can be used to design catalytic nanomotors with different dynamic behaviors. In this project, we will address the following objectives: (1) to design nanomotors with different dynamic properties, (2) to characterize the nanomotors and their motion behaviors, (3) to explore the use of alternative fuel and the control of the nanomotors motion.
The success of this project will open a door for us to access and design different novel nano-motion components, and will catalyze rapid and innovative advances not only in fabricating nanomotor components, but also in designing and integrating novel nanomachines. With further functionalization and motion control, implications of those nanomotors in NEMS, drug delivery, disease treatment, etc, are greatly expected. In addition, this project will also establish a rigorous material physics and nanotechnology education and training opportunity for graduate and undergraduate students, and even high school students.

Institution.Name: University of Georgia Research Foundation Inc
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA RESEARCH FOUNDATION, INC.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Controlled motion of nanoscale objects is the first step to achieve integrated nanomachinary systems that can enable break-through applications in nanoelectronics, photonics, bioengineering, and drug delivery or disease treatment. Naturally occurring nanomotors are biological motor proteins powered by catalytic reactions. Unlike the nanomotors in nature, most artificial nanomotors are usually powered by external fields. Recently it has been demonstrated that using a simple catalytic reaction and an asymmetric bimetallic nanorod, one can produce catalytic nanomotors that mimic certain dynamic behaviors of bionanomotors. This research has shined a light for humans to be able to construct complicated nanomachines which mimic biological behavior. Yet, the construction of artificial nanomachines remains a major contemporary challenge due to the lack of a flexible fabrication technique that can design the desired dynamic components. Recent research in our laboratories has demonstrated that a nanofabrication technique based on shadowing growth and dynamic substrate manipulation can be used to design catalytic nanomotors with different dynamic behaviors.  When compared to other nanofabrication methods to produce nanomotors, this method offers several strategic advantages including: (1) precise control of the size, shape, orientation and composition of the backbone nanorod and the location of the catalyst deposition, (2) multilayer deposition and three-dimensional structure/nanomotor design, and (3) implementation of the method using relatively simple procedures.

In this project, we aim to address the following specific aims: (1) to design nanomotors with different dynamic properties, (2) to characterize the nanomotors and their motion behaviors, (3) to explore the use of alternative fuel (glucose) and the control of the nanomotors motion.

During the four-year project period, we have focused on the following aspects: (1) design nanomotors with different motion properties, and obtain the optimum fabrication conditions to achieve relative large scale production; (2)  examine the relationship between the structure of the nanomotors and their dynamic properties, and gain a better understanding of the propelling mechanism due to the catalytic reaction; and explore the use of the alternative fuel (glucose) and the control of the nanomotors motion. We have demonstrated that we can engineer different catalytic nanomotors, such as rotary rods, L-shaped rods, helices, index-like rod, and tadpole like motors, using the dynamic shadowing growth methods. The shape of the nanostructure and the location of the catalyst dominate the motion behaviors. We have performed detailed experiments to investigate how the motions are different for the index nanomotors and tadpole like nanomotors since the geometric shape of these two motors are similar while the catalyst location is different. In addition, the fine-tune of the shape of tadpole nanomotors on the motion behavior has been studied both experimentally and theoretically. By changing the length of the tail of the tadpole nanomotors, one can control the motion trajectory. We also carried out a detailed experiment to measure the force that drive the motion of the nanomotors. It is in the range of 10^-13 Newton, depending on the concentration of the H2O2. The detailed motion mechanism has been investigated. We have proposed a bubble injection model, and our theoretical prediction fits quite well with experimental results. Since the ultimate goal of this project is to assemble motion part into future nanomachine, one has to assemble different motion parts together to form a complicated nanomachine. For the first time, we have assembled multiple component nanomotors using different interactions. With the mechanical interlock, we can pin two tadpole nanomotors together to form a new nanomotor. To form a helicopter like nan...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Controlled motion of nanoscale objects is the first step to achieve integrated nanomachinary systems that can enable break-through applications in nanoelectronics, photonics, bioengineering, and drug delivery or disease treatment. Naturally occurring nanomotors are biological motor proteins powered by catalytic reactions. Unlike the nanomotors in nature, most artificial nanomotors are usually powered by external fields. Recently it has been demonstrated that using a simple catalytic reaction and an asymmetric bimetallic nanorod, one can produce catalytic nanomotors that mimic certain dynamic behaviors of bionanomotors. This research has shined a light for humans to be able to construct complicated nanomachines which mimic biological behavior. Yet, the construction of artificial nanomachines remains a major contemporary challenge due to the lack of a flexible fabrication technique that can design the desired dynamic components. Recent research in our laboratories has demonstrated that a nanofabrication technique based on shadowing growth and dynamic substrate manipulation can be used to design catalytic nanomotors with different dynamic behaviors. When compared to other nanofabrication methods to produce nanomotors, this method offers several strategic advantages including: (1) precise control of the size, shape, orientation and composition of the backbone nanorod and the location of the catalyst deposition, (2) multilayer deposition and three-dimensional structure/nanomotor design, and (3) implementation of the method using relatively simple procedures. In this project, we aim to address the following specific aims: (1) to design nanomotors with different dynamic properties, (2) to characterize the nanomotors and their motion behaviors, (3) to explore the use of alternative fuel (glucose) and the control of the nanomotors motion. During the four-year project period, we have focused on the following aspects: (1) design nanomotors with different motion properties, and obtain the optimum fabrication conditions to achieve relative large scale production; (2) examine the relationship between the structure of the nanomotors and their dynamic properties, and gain a better understanding of the propelling mechanism due to the catalytic reaction; and explore the use of the alternative fuel (glucose) and the control of the nanomotors motion. We have demonstrated that we can engineer different catalytic nanomotors, such as rotary rods, L-shaped rods, helices, index-like rod, and tadpole like motors, using the dynamic shadowing growth methods. The shape of the nanostructure and the location of the catalyst dominate the motion behaviors. We have performed detailed experiments to investigate how the motions are different for the index nanomotors and tadpole like nanomotors since the geometric shape of these two motors are similar while the catalyst location is different. In addition, the fine-tune of the shape of tadpole nanomotors on the motion behavior has been studied both experimentally and theoretically. By changing the length of the tail of the tadpole nanomotors, one can control the motion trajectory. We also carried out a detailed experiment to measure the force that drive the motion of the nanomotors. It is in the range of 10^-13 Newton, depending on the concentration of the H2O2. The detailed motion mechanism has been investigated. We have proposed a bubble injection model, and our theoretical prediction fits quite well with experimental results. Since the ultimate goal of this project is to assemble motion part into future nanomachine, one has to assemble different motion parts together to form a complicated nanomachine. For the first time, we have assembled multiple component nanomotors using different interactions. With the mechanical interlock, we can pin two tadpole nanomotors together to form a new nanomotor.
